Dog Ban Postponed UntilSeptember First
BY BARBARA BUSHARIS
The Student Council voted
at its meeting Wednesday night
to create an ad hoc committee
to investigate the problem of
dogs on campus, in response to
the new regulations issued by
the administration.
The measure will delay the
enforcement of the present ban
on dogs until September 1,
1981.
The controversy began with
a memo from Dean George
Owen stating that dogs would
no longer be allowed on campus
unless their owners were directly
responsible for them. Also, dogs
would no longer be allowed in
any University building, includThe new
ing apartments.
regulation took effect February
1,1981.

Junior Ellen Kavee began a
protest movement that resulted
in petitions that have now been
signed by approximately 1200
students. The signers objected
to the manner in which the
Administration went about developing and publicizing the new
rules. They suggested that a
student-administration discussion of
the issue could create "a better
solution than a blanket ban."
Kavee said that only 10
percent of the students approached to sign the petitions
refused to get involved. More
than 80% supported the protest;
some were dog lovers, but others
simply resented the University's
approach, she said.
Kavee proposed the establishment of a student committee
to regulate dogs on campus.
All dogs would be registered and

tagged for a $2 fee. Complaints
against a specific dog could be
registered with the committee,
which would decide upon the
appropriate disciplinary action
(including fines and/or loss of
campus privileges).
Kavee noted that when
Dean Hall was first approached
with the plan for a regulatory
committee, he discouraged it.
One objection, Kavee believes,
was the proposal that complaints
be called in to the University.
switchboard.
The plan was
subsequently modified to direct
the calls to the Student Council
office.
At the Student Council
meeting, President
Michael
Steele revealed that he had
spoken with Dean Owen about
the problem. Owen conceded
that the new policy was

"tough," said Steele.
Council members suggested
that enforcement of the policy
be delayed until September 1.
This would give a student
committee time to investigate
the problem, review policy, and
recommend a course of action
that would be "fairer" to all
concerned. Steele added that
extension of the deadline would
give students time to find new
housing for their pets if necessary. He asked for the Council
to approve the creation of an ad
hoc committee to deal with the
problem.
"I'm pleased with the decision," said Kavee. Although the
new committee will serve only
to investigate, rather than regulate, the dog problem, she sees ii
as representing "a more lenient
attitude."

otherwise pleasant, happy events
into grotesque parodies of what
was once a good thing, all in the
name of Commercialism. The
release of the American hostages
was no exception:
before
anyone had an opportunity to

tell us what personal significance

before anyone else had the
chance to tell us what personal

and ugly as usual.

common knowledge. Most major

get right down to writing a
book on the subject.

television news, and still photographs.
The writers locked
themselves in seclusion for two

Sorry, No Fight This Time
The firing of Marge Mareck, formerly a
secretary at the University's Eisenhower
Project, has all the right ingredients for yet
another Us vs. Them standoff. There is the
Exploited Employee, whose only crime was
to ask for more money; there is the Administration, acting through its usual haze
of Official Blather; there are the Angry
Students, demanding in sanctimonious
terms that the rights of the "exploited' be
protected; and there is even an Evil Employer, bad Dr. Galambos, spewing forth
orders faster than anyone could take.
Fortunately, one simple thing saves us
from such a confrontation--Mrs. Mareck
simply doesn't have a case.
The S500 pay increase she demanded
may indeed have been merited; that is not
the issue. There has to be a casual link
between her request and her firing for her
to claim an injustice—and, unless someone
really is hiding something, that link doesn't
9

exist.
For whatever reasons, working
relations do deteriorate--something that
both Mareck and Galambos acknowledge.
Those involved in the formation of the
Johns Hopkins Employees Association
should, however, be praised. There is no
reason to believe that this University, as an
employer is any less generally mean and
rotten than anyone else. Rather than
harping about sporadic cases of perceived
wrongdoing, the Association seems willing
to work towards a better situation for
both sides (and dropping the idea of

Let's get back to the add/drop date and

grade—it's like a dry run," explained Dean
Michael Hooker in an interview with the NewsLetter this week. "This happens more in labs

kind of dry run experience will enhance your
chances of getting a good grade the second time
around."

date. The CUS took up the matter at its January 27 meeting this year. At its next meeting,

down on the number of drop slips coming
around, the changes in programs, and the
problems that creates for the Registrar's Office,
I'm proposing that every add/drop slip be signed

interview this Tuesday. "It's possible now for a
student to go to his advisor and sign up for
five courses and then by the use of add/drops
change that list completely from what it was
originally intended to be. The fact that people
will have to go see their advisors to get anything
changed will result in less arbitrary course
selection. I see this as a compromise. I don't
think it's the ideal situation;!• would prefer to
keep the add/drop dates as they are."

a small seminar and you structure your course so

gaps in the course. They would like to see the
instructor's permission required to drop a course
after three weeks as well as an advisor's. Now
that I'm not too sure about. I mean that is

Chuck Peifer, one of CUS voting undergraduates,

schedule that it sort of cements them in."

the present add date, make the drop date six

eight), and require advisors' signatures on all
add/drop slips after the third week of classes.
Peifer's proposal leaves the drop date

of

cont. from p. 13
sharp lines and angles, checkered areas,
circles, triangles, curves, distorted ovals
and trapezoids. Elements overlap and
stand in formation side by side, lines
crisscross and veer off into zigzag
thickets, acute angles chop semicircles
into arabesques. In Bright Sound two
stalks snap forward from a translucent
yellow triangle, sweeping chips of color
into random parquet and leaving in their
wake a barely balanced structure, here
and there points of invisible intersection,
and staves tumbling over screened-off
yellow glow.
On Violet, Free Relationship, and
Daybreak are some of the amazing
watercolors which epitomize Kandinsky':
most distinctive style. These works seerrto exude tension: tension between exact
and inexact, complete and fragmented
forms; between main forms and constellations of miscellaneous elements. It is
impossible to tell whether a picture is on
the verge of integration or in the process
of explosion.
Kandinsky rejected the notion
that abstract painting must confine itself
to a single picture plane. His paintings
establish a uniquely ambiguous space-sometimes shallow, sometimes naturalistic. Forms spread out over a homogenous plane, and we are not impelled to see
an illusory space around objects, yet we
do not see one single surface either.
Kandinsky uses visual clues, such as
shading and convergent lines, in contradictory ways. Colors play against each
other and against linear forms so that
elements of the picture appear to be
floating freely in some "new" space.
Kandinsky's paintings are particularly susceptible to interpretation as
realistic scenes: "The triangle looks like a
man, the circle is a sun," and so forth.
Indeed, there are many forms which
demand to be read in realistic terms, and
which Kandinsky must have included
deliberately. For example, On Violet
looks like ,a surrealistic cartoon: a boat
chugs uphill past a huge hair, towards a

bridge. But even when there are no
explicit resemblances, the geometrical
paintings seem to imply a reality through
sheer expressive energy. This is because
most of the forms derive from objects in
the world. Kandinsky's abstractional
method puts images from his own visual
experience through a sieve. For him the
important thing was that the object lose
its identity as a concrete fixture of the
world with a certain material function;
then a viewer might concentrate on the
way it looks rather than on what it is.
Kandinsky employed circles, triangles,
and squares, and separated line and color
not in order to present these things as
"pure" entities in their own right, but to
concentrate with great specificity one
aspect of an image while reducing and
filtering out others.
Kandinsky's late- and postBauhaus watercolors reveal increasingly
sophisticated technique.
Watercolor
mists applied with an atomizer, spatters,
and multiple washes contribute to simpler
compositions which rely more on color.
Throughout the 1930s Kandinsky's work
becomes much more controlled and
simplified—the explosive detail so characteristic of his Bauhaus watercolors
disappears. Finally, in the 1940s, his
paintings acquire a biomorphic quality, as
well as renewed complexity.
Kandinsky's paintings renounce
ties with the visible, but not ties with
reality. Individual components are pure
invention, yet the whole painting constitutes a poetry of forms linked analogically and metaphorically to reality. We see a
painting full of strange shapes, planes of
color, lines, grids, figure, and ground--a
visual field resolved into a visual world
only by an act of imagination.
Kandinsky has given us a world in which
spatial relationship are different from our
own, which contains objects that do not
occur in our experience, but which
convince us as representatives of the
hidden and mysterious reality behind the
world of appearance.

sharp lines and angles, checkered areas,
circles, triangles, curves, distorted ovals
and trapezoids. Elements overlap and
stand in formation side by side, lines
crisscross and veer off into zigzag
thickets, acute angles chop semicircles
into arabesques. In Bright Sound two
stalks snap forward from a translucent
yellow triangle, sweeping chips of color
into random parquet and leaving in their
wake a barely balanced structure, here
and there points of invisible intersection,
and staves tumbling over screened-off
yellow glow.
On Violet, Free Relationship, and
Daybreak are some of the amazing
watercolors which epitomize Kandinsky':
most distinctive style. These works seerrto exude tension: tension between exact
and inexact, complete and fragmented
forms; between main forms and constellations of miscellaneous elements. It is
impossible to tell whether a picture is on
the verge of integration or in the process
of explosion.
Kandinsky rejected the notion
that abstract painting must confine itself
to a single picture plane. His paintings
establish a uniquely ambiguous space-sometimes shallow, sometimes naturalistic. Forms spread out over a homogenous plane, and we are not impelled to see
an illusory space around objects, yet we
do not see one single surface either.
Kandinsky uses visual clues, such as
shading and convergent lines, in contradictory ways. Colors play against each
other and against linear forms so that
elements of the picture appear to be
floating freely in some "new" space.
Kandinsky's paintings are particularly susceptible to interpretation as
realistic scenes: "The triangle looks like a
man, the circle is a sun," and so forth.
Indeed, there are many forms which
demand to be read in realistic terms, and
which Kandinsky must have included
deliberately. For example, On Violet
looks like ,a surrealistic cartoon: a boat
chugs uphill past a huge hair, towards a

bridge. But even when there are no
explicit resemblances, the geometrical
paintings seem to imply a reality through
sheer expressive energy. This is because
most of the forms derive from objects in
the world. Kandinsky's abstractional
method puts images from his own visual
experience through a sieve. For him the
important thing was that the object lose
its identity as a concrete fixture of the
world with a certain material function;
then a viewer might concentrate on the
way it looks rather than on what it is.
Kandinsky employed circles, triangles,
and squares, and separated line and color
not in order to present these things as
"pure" entities in their own right, but to
concentrate with great specificity one
aspect of an image while reducing and
filtering out others.
Kandinsky's late- and postBauhaus watercolors reveal increasingly
sophisticated technique.
Watercolor
mists applied with an atomizer, spatters,
and multiple washes contribute to simpler
compositions which rely more on color.
Throughout the 1930s Kandinsky's work
becomes much more controlled and
simplified—the explosive detail so characteristic of his Bauhaus watercolors
disappears. Finally, in the 1940s, his
paintings acquire a biomorphic quality, as
well as renewed complexity.
Kandinsky's paintings renounce
ties with the visible, but not ties with
reality. Individual components are pure
invention, yet the whole painting constitutes a poetry of forms linked analogically and metaphorically to reality. We see a
painting full of strange shapes, planes of
color, lines, grids, figure, and ground--a
visual field resolved into a visual world
only by an act of imagination.
Kandinsky has given us a world in which
spatial relationship are different from our
own, which contains objects that do not
occur in our experience, but which
convince us as representatives of the
hidden and mysterious reality behind the
world of appearance.
